intro: Biropteris antri-jovis, commonly known as the cave fern, is a rare and unique plant species native to the tropical regions of Central and South America. It is characterized by its delicate fronds that resemble those of other members of the Dryopteridaceae family, though it exhibits distinctive features such as its finely divided, lace-like patterns. This fern thrives in humid, shaded environments, often found growing on rock surfaces or in cave systems where it can access the moisture it requires. Its botanical significance lies in its adaptability to extreme microhabitats, making it a subject of interest for botanists studying plant survival in challenging conditions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Biropteris antri-jovis is considered a vulnerable species.
